title: Authors and Citation
text: Bohyn Alexandre. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Alexandre B (2024). hsds: Data sets "Handbook Small Data Sets", Hand et al. (1994). R package version 0.1.0, https://abohyndoe.github.io/HSDS/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {hsds: Data sets from the "Handbook of Small Data Sets", Hand et al. (1994)},   author = {Bohyn Alexandre},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://abohyndoe.github.io/HSDS/}, }

title: Data sets from the
text: goal HSDS make data sets book “Handbook Small Data Sets” (1994) David J. Hand available. data sets particularly useful demonstrate examples function statistical tests, also teach statistics R. data sets already available individually repo: https://github.com/JedStephens/Handbook--Small-Data-Sets/tree/master. However, immediately usable R, undocumented. package aims solve issue, provide clean documented data sets. like package want support ?

title: Data sets from the
text: can install development version HSDS like :

title: Data sets from the
text: book contains 500 data sets. moment, available. summarized table , along names, contain, structure, type variables present.

title: Data sets from the
text: basic example shows use data set make nice plot:
code: library(HSDS) library(ggplot2)  ggplot(germin, aes(x = water, y = seeds, color = box)) +   geom_boxplot(na.rm = T) +   theme_bw()

title: Data sets from the
text: far 500 data sets, help welcome ! want contribute, raw data sets already present repo (data-raw/data-files), feel free clean one … ! , please respect following guidelines: data sets named data structure index book (available ) variables data set labelled (using labelled package example) data sets documented using text book

title: Abrasion loss — abrasion
text: Data experiment investigate resistance ruhher abrasion affected hardness ruhher tensile strength.

title: Abrasion loss — abrasion
text: data frame 30 rows 3 columns: abrasion_loss Loss rubber fixed period time (grams   per hour) hardness Hardness rubber degrees Shore (larger   number, harder rubber) tensile_strength Tensile strength rubber (kg per squared   centimetres)

title: Abrasion loss — abrasion
text: Davies, O.L. Goldsmith, P.L. (eds.) (1972) Statistical   Methods Research Production, 4th Edition, Edinburgh: Oliverand   Boyd, 239.

title: Abrasion loss — abrasion
text: 30 samples rubber tested hardness (degrees Shore; larger number, harder rubber) tensile strength (measured kg per square centimetre), subjected steady abrasion fixed time. weight loss due abrasion measured grams per hour. data analysed regression two explanatory variables.

title: Abrasion loss — abrasion
code: data(abrasion) mod <- lm(abrasion_loss ~ tensile_strength + hardness, data = abrasion) summary(mod) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = abrasion_loss ~ tensile_strength + hardness, data = abrasion) #>  #> Residuals: #>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max  #> -79.385 -14.608   3.816  19.755  65.981  #>  #> Coefficients: #>                  Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept)      885.1611    61.7516  14.334 3.84e-14 *** #> tensile_strength  -1.3743     0.1943  -7.073 1.32e-07 *** #> hardness          -6.5708     0.5832 -11.267 1.03e-11 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 36.49 on 27 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared:  0.8402,	Adjusted R-squared:  0.8284  #> F-statistic:    71 on 2 and 27 DF,  p-value: 1.767e-11 #>   plot(abrasion$hardness, abrasion$abrasion_loss, xlab = "Hardness", ylab = "Abrasion loss")

title: Tensile strength of cement — cement
text: Tensile strength different batches cement different curing times. tensile strength cement depends (among things) length time cement dried 'cured'. relationship curing time strength non-linear. Hald regresses log tensile strength reciprocal curing time.

title: Tensile strength of cement — cement
text: data frame 21 rows 2 columns: time Curing time days strength Tensile strength (kg/cm2)

title: Tensile strength of cement — cement
text: Hald, . (1952) Statistical Theory Engineering   Applications, New York: John Wiley & Sons, 451.

title: Tensile strength of cement — cement
code: library(ggplot2) library(hsds)  # There is a clear non-linear relation between time and strength # Hald regresses log tensile strength on the reciprocal of curing time.  ggplot(cement, aes(y = strength, x = time)) +   geom_point() +   geom_smooth(method = "lm", formula = y ~ exp(1 / x), se = FALSE) +   theme_classic(base_size = 12)   # Using Hald's method the relationship is clearly linear ggplot(cement, aes(y = log(strength), x = 1 / time)) +   geom_point() +   geom_smooth(method = "lm", formula = y ~ x, se = FALSE) +   theme_classic(base_size = 12)   # A linear model indeed fits well (high R-squared) and # the reciprocal of time is significant lm(log(strength) ~ I(1 / time), data = cement) |>   summary() #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = log(strength) ~ I(1/time), data = cement) #>  #> Residuals: #>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max  #> -0.12376 -0.04601  0.01679  0.05098  0.10495  #>  #> Coefficients: #>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept)  3.68782    0.02425  152.06  < 2e-16 *** #> I(1/time)   -1.14553    0.05290  -21.66 7.47e-15 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 0.07557 on 19 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared:  0.9611,	Adjusted R-squared:  0.959  #> F-statistic: 468.9 on 1 and 19 DF,  p-value: 7.473e-15 #>

title: Weight of chickens — chickens
text: Data randomized blocked experiment investigate effect drug added feed chicks attempt promote growth. comparison three treatments: standard feed (control), standard feed plus low dose drug, standard feed plus high dose drug. experimental unit group chicks, reared fed together birdhouse. experimental units grouped three block, physically adjacent units going block.

title: Weight of chickens — chickens
text: data frame 24 rows 3 columns: block Block corresponding bird house dose Dose drug added diet (`control`, `low` `high`) weight Average weight per bird (pounds) maturity group   birds experimental unit

title: Weight of chickens — chickens
text: Snee, R.D. (1985) Graphical display results   three-treatment randomized block experiments. Applied Statistics, 34,   71-7.

title: Weight of chickens — chickens
code: library(hsds) library(ggplot2) library(lme4) #> Error in library(lme4): there is no package called ‘lme4’  # Plot of the average weight per diet, on top of a box plot ggplot(chickens, aes(x = dose, y = weight)) +   geom_boxplot(color = "gray") +   geom_line(aes(color = block, group = block)) +   geom_point(aes(color = block), size = 2) +   theme_classic()   # Model of the weight by dose, taking into account the random variation within # each individual unit mod <- lmer(weight ~ dose + (1 | block), data = chickens) #> Error in lmer(weight ~ dose + (1 | block), data = chickens): could not find function "lmer" summary(mod) #> Error: object 'mod' not found  # The `modelbased` package is great to estimate marginal means modelbased::estimate_means(mod, at = c("dose")) #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘modelbased’  # Or to estimate contrasts to see if there is a significant difference in weight # between diets modelbased::estimate_contrasts(mod, contrast = "dose", p_adjust = "tukey") #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘modelbased’

what: Effect of ammonium chloride on yield — chloride
title: Effect of ammonium chloride on yield — chloride
text: Data experiment investigate yield organic chemical process used ammonium chloride.

title: Effect of ammonium chloride on yield — chloride
Effect of ammonium chloride on yield — chloride
text: data frame 32 rows 5 columns: block Experimental block unit Production unit amount Ammonium chloride amount, `low` `high` quality Ammonium chloride quality, `low` `high` yield Process yield pounds

title: Effect of ammonium chloride on yield — chloride
text: Davies, O.L. (ed.) (1956) Design Analysis   Industrial Experiments, 2nd Edition, London: Longman, 375.

title: Effect of ammonium chloride on yield — chloride
text: main interest lay comparison use finely ground coarse ammonium chloride; fine grade cost . experimenters also interested effect adding extra 10 usual amount. two production units plant, thought unit used effect yield, interactions unit two factors involving ammonium chloride unlikely. experiment thus 23 factorial treatment structure. Experimental runs carried blocks, block using blend input materials, desirable blends large. Therefore complete randomized block design considered appropriate; instead, blocks size 4 used 3-way interaction confounded blocks.

title: Effect of ammonium chloride on yield — chloride
code: library(hsds) library(ggplot2)  # Two-way interaction plot between amount and quality chloride %>%   dplyr::filter(!is.na(yield)) %>%   ggplot(aes(x = amount, y = yield, color = quality, group = quality)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   facet_wrap(     . ~ block,     nrow = 2,     labeller = labeller(.rows = ~paste0("Block ", .x))   ) +   theme_classic() #> Error in chloride %>% dplyr::filter(!is.na(yield)) %>% ggplot(aes(x = amount,     y = yield, color = quality, group = quality)): could not find function "%>%"

title: Comparing dish washing detergents — dishwash
text: experiment carried compare dish washing detergents. Standard plates soiled standard dirt, operator washed plates detergent solution one time. response variable number plates washed foam disappeared. Three basins set , operator , three Operators took care wash rate. different detergent used basin. Thus experimental unit single washing-session one basin, units grouped blocks three (washing-sessions carried simultaneously). Since nine detergents compare blocks size three, balanced incomplete block design used.

title: Comparing dish washing detergents — dishwash
text: data frame 36 rows 3 columns: block Washing session. Factor levels '1' '12' detergent Detergent brand. Factor levels '1' '9' plates Number plates washed foam disappeared

title: Comparing dish washing detergents — dishwash
text: John, P.W.M. (1961) application balanced incomplete   block design, Technometrics, 3, 51-54.

title: Comparing dish washing detergents — dishwash
code: library(dplyr) #> Error in library(dplyr): there is no package called ‘dplyr’ library(tidyr) #> Error in library(tidyr): there is no package called ‘tidyr’ library(gt) #> Error in library(gt): there is no package called ‘gt’ library(hsds)  # Generate all possible cases of detergent and block, then add the recorded # values from the experiment all_cases <- dishwash %>%   expand(block, detergent) %>%   left_join(dishwash, by = join_by(block, detergent)) #> Error in dishwash %>% expand(block, detergent) %>% left_join(dishwash,     by = join_by(block, detergent)): could not find function "%>%"  # Display as a visually appealling table, showing the incomplete blocked design # structure all_cases %>%   labelled::set_variable_labels(plates = NULL) %>%   pivot_wider(     names_from = "detergent",     values_from = "plates"   ) %>%   gt() %>%   sub_missing() %>%   cols_label(block ~ "Block") %>%   tab_spanner("Detergent", columns = -block) %>%   cols_width(everything() ~ px(40)) #> Error in all_cases %>% labelled::set_variable_labels(plates = NULL) %>%     pivot_wider(names_from = "detergent", values_from = "plates") %>%     gt() %>% sub_missing() %>% cols_label(block ~ "Block") %>%     tab_spanner("Detergent", columns = -block) %>% cols_width(everything() ~     px(40)): could not find function "%>%"

title: Flicker frequency — flicker
text: undesirable side-effect antihistamines drowsiness, consequence effect drugs central nervous system. data come experiment compare placebo two anti-histaminic drugs effect central nervous system. can done measuring called flicker frequency volunteers taken treatments. experiment 9 subjects, took one three treatments three days. experimental unit thus subject-day combination. design experiment based three 3 x 3 latin squares columns (days) permuted randomly separately square, rows (subjects) permuted using random permutation 1, 2, ... , 9. three treatments labelled (meclastine, new anti-histaminic drug), B (placebo) C (promethazine, established anti-histaminic drug known cause drowsiness).

title: Flicker frequency — flicker
text: data frame 27 rows 4 columns: subject subject ID day Day experiment frequency Flicker frequency treatment Anti-histaminic treatment given, one `meclastine`, `placebo`, `promethazine`

title: Flicker frequency — flicker
text: Hedges, ., Hills, M., Maclay, W.P., Newman-Taylor, .J. Turner,   P. (1971) central peripheral effects meclastine, new   antihistaminic drug, man. Journal Clinical Pharmacology, 2, 112-119

title: Flicker frequency — flicker
code: library(ggplot2) library(patchwork) #> Error in library(patchwork): there is no package called ‘patchwork’ library(hsds)  # Plot variation within days, treatments and subjects ## Days p_days <- ggplot(flicker, aes(x = day, y = frequency)) +   geom_boxplot(color = "gray") +   geom_jitter(width = 0.1) +   theme_classic() ## Treatments p_treat <- ggplot(flicker, aes(x = treatment, y = frequency)) +   geom_boxplot(color = "gray") +   geom_jitter(width = 0.1) +   theme_classic() ## Subjects p_subj <- ggplot(flicker, aes(x = subject, y = frequency)) +   geom_boxplot(color = "gray") +   geom_jitter(width = 0.1) +   theme_classic() # Combine using the `patchwork` package p_days + p_treat + p_subj + plot_layout(nrow = 2) #> Error in ggplot_add(object, p, objectname): Can't add `p_treat` to a <ggplot> object.  # Mixed model with random effects for day and subject mod <- lmer(frequency ~ treatment + (1 | subject) + (1 | day), data = flicker) #> Error in lmer(frequency ~ treatment + (1 | subject) + (1 | day), data = flicker): could not find function "lmer"  # Plot of the marginal means per treatment, using the `modelbased` package modelbased::estimate_means(mod, at = c("treatment")) |>   plot() +   theme_classic() #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘modelbased’  # Table of the contrast between treatments, using the `modelbased` package modelbased::estimate_contrasts(mod, contrast = "treatment") #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘modelbased’

title: Weight gain in rats — weight
text: data come experiment study gain weight rats fed four different diets, distinguished amount protein (low high) source protein (beef cereal). design experiment completely randomized ten rats four treatments (complete factorial structure).

title: Weight gain in rats — weight
text: data frame 30 rows 3 columns: weight Weight gain grams source Protein source (`beef` `cereal`) amount Protein amount (`low` `high`)

title: Weight gain in rats — weight
text: Snedecor, G.W. Cochran, G.C. (1967) Statistical Methods,   6th edition, Ames, Iowa: Iowa State University Press, 347.

title: Weight gain in rats — weight
code: library(hsds) library(ggplot2)  # Mean weight gain per diet weight %>%   dplyr::summarise(     mean(weight),     sd(weight),     .by = c(source, amount)   ) #> Error in weight %>% dplyr::summarise(mean(weight), sd(weight), .by = c(source,     amount)): could not find function "%>%"  # Colored box plot ggplot(weight, aes(x = amount, y = weight, color = source)) +   geom_boxplot() +   geom_jitter(position = position_dodge(width = 0.75)) +   theme_classic()   # Two-way ANOVA aov(weight ~ amount * source, data = weight) %>%   summary() #> Error in aov(weight ~ amount * source, data = weight) %>% summary(): could not find function "%>%"
